feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: Operational reality summary for "daily wage calculator" based on Jira evidence: - Findings / issues / limitations: 44 - Troubleshooting / edge cases / requests: 25 - Evidence suggests asynchronous updates or synchronization considerations. - Evidence includes UI/visibility or copy/label concerns.

findings.group_description: The system cannot automatically calculate salary based on actual working days (e.g., 26 working days per month standard) with dynamic adjustments for extra or fewer worked days. This requires manual tracking and separate adjustments per employee, creating operational overhead.
findings.issue_explanation: Client requested automated salary payout where employees are paid full salary for 26 working days, with extra days adding to salary and fewer days reducing it proportionally. Support confirmed this is not currently supported in the payroll system and cannot be easily implemented via workflows.
findings.limitation_statement: The current payroll system cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally when employees work more or fewer than the standard 26 working days per month without manual intervention.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks automated, attendance-driven salary calculation. It cannot automatically pro-rata salary adjustments per employee based on actual working days; instead, it requires manual tracking of overtime and unpaid leaves as separate adjustments.

findings.group_description: Workflows cannot be used to automate salary proration based on working days. The support team indicated this is not easy to implement on the payroll side, leaving no automation pathway for this use case.
findings.issue_explanation: Client asked if this could be implemented via workflows. Support response confirmed it is not something easy to implement on the payroll side and no workflow solution exists for automated salary proration.
findings.limitation_statement: Payroll workflows do not support automated salary calculation and proration based on working days.

findings.group_description: Users are confused when daily wage formulas in leave policy appear greyed out and differ from payroll settings. The system lacks clear visual communication that payroll-side daily wage calculator configuration overrides leave policy formulas for unpaid leave deductions.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket reports that when a user configures unpaid leave in leave policy, the daily wage formula displayed is greyed out and does not match the formula configured in payroll settings. The system comment confirms this is working as designed: payroll settings override leave policy. However, the greyed-out display does not clearly communicate this override mechanism to users.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform lacks clear visual communication about formula override mechanisms. Users cannot easily understand why formulas are greyed out or how payroll settings supersede leave policy configurations.
findings.gap_statement: There is no synchronized mechanism for daily wage formula configuration between leave policy and payroll modules. The system requires manual alignment and does not provide automatic formula inheritance or synchronization.

findings.group_description: Users expect daily wage formulas to be synchronized or reflected consistently across leave policy and payroll settings. The system intentionally allows payroll configuration to override leave policy, but this precedence rule is not clearly documented or communicated.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket shows user expectation that 'the formula under payroll settings should be reflected same under the leave policy.' The system comment clarifies that payroll-side daily wage calculator takes precedence and overwrites leave policy configuration. This is intentional behavior but creates confusion because the override hierarchy is not transparent.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not provide bidirectional synchronization between leave policy and payroll daily wage calculator configurations. Once payroll settings are configured, leave policy formulas become read-only (greyed out) without clear indication of why.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation and UI do not clearly explain the formula precedence rule: payroll daily wage calculator overrides leave policy formulas for unpaid leave deductions.

findings.group_description: When a new salary configuration is created after an unpaid leave request is submitted, the system fails to automatically recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions. The deduction continues to use the previous (outdated) salary configuration, resulting in incorrect payroll deduction amounts. This creates a critical synchronization gap between salary changes and leave deduction calculations.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents a specific case where an employee (Manu Chandran) took 21 days unpaid leave in March 2024. The expected deduction based on current salary was AED 3,625.40 (calculated as 5250/30.41 * 21), but the actual deduction shown was AED 3,383.76. Development team confirmed the root cause: the deduction was calculated based on the employee's previous salary configuration because the latest salary config had not been created by the time the unpaid leave was created. The system did not automatically update pending unpaid leave deduction amounts when a new salary configuration was subsequently created.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform cannot automatically recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations are created after leave request submission.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks dynamic salary configuration handling to automatically update pending leave deductions when salary configurations change. Manual intervention is required to ensure accurate calculations.

findings.group_description: When unpaid leave deductions are calculated incorrectly due to stale salary configuration, users must manually delete the leave request and recreate it to trigger recalculation. This workaround is only viable if the deduction has not yet been processed into payroll, creating operational friction during time-sensitive payroll closure periods.
findings.issue_explanation: The development team provided a workaround for the stale salary configuration bug: delete the leave request and create it again if the deduction has not been processed yet. This manual intervention is necessary because the system does not automatically update pending unpaid leave deduction amounts when salary configurations change. The ticket notes this workaround was critical for the customer who needed to close payroll urgently.
findings.limitation_statement: Users must manually delete and recreate leave requests to force recalculation of unpaid leave deductions when salary configurations have changed.

findings.group_description: The EOS gratuity calculator fails to recognize leap years (366 days) and instead uses 365 days for all years. This causes incorrect total service day calculations and results in underpayment of gratuity benefits. For the reported case, the system calculated 607 days instead of the correct 608 days, resulting in AED 10,476.98 instead of the correct AED 10,494.24.
findings.issue_explanation: When calculating End of Service gratuity for employee Nabil Kachlan (joining 09/11/2023, exit 08/07/2025), the system did not account for 2024 being a leap year. The correct calculation should include 53 days (2023) + 366 days (2024) + 189 days (2025) = 608 days. However, the system calculated 53 + 365 + 189 = 607 days, treating 2024 as a standard 365-day year. This resulted in 1.6630 years instead of 1.6657 years, and a final gratuity of AED 10,476.98 instead of AED 10,494.24 (verified correct by MOHRE).
findings.limitation_statement: The platform's gratuity calculation logic does not automatically adjust for leap years, causing inaccurate service period calculations and potential underpayment of employee benefits.
findings.gap_statement: The EOS gratuity calculator lacks dynamic leap year handling. The system requires enhancement to automatically recognize and incorporate 366-day years in service period computations.

findings.group_description: End of Service pro-rated amount calculations produce incorrect values due to decimal precision errors. The system consistently shows amounts less than expected by 0.1 to 0.2 decimals (e.g., 89,999.9 instead of 9000), affecting all employees regardless of departure date.
findings.issue_explanation: When daily wage calculation is configured as 'basic + allowances / 30' and applied to End of Service calculations, the system exhibits a systematic undercalculation. For example, an employee with 27K salary and a 10 September departure date should receive 9000 in pro-rated amount, but the system shows 89,999.9 instead. This decimal precision error is consistent across all employees.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform's daily wage calculation engine cannot accurately compute pro-rated amounts with correct decimal precision in End of Service scenarios.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks adequate rounding and decimal handling mechanisms to ensure exact financial calculations in pro-rated salary computations.

findings.group_description: Admin observed a discrepancy between system-calculated EOS gratuity (AED 231,821.10) and manual calculation (AED 252,485). Support confirmed the system calculation is correct based on service duration split and tiered daily wage formula (21 days/year for years 1-5, 30 days/year for years 5+). The discrepancy was due to admin misunderstanding of the calculation methodology.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents a gratuity calculation for employee with hire date 01/07/2007 and departure date 17/10/2025. System correctly calculated: service duration 18 years 3 months 17 days, daily wage 460 (13,800/30), first 5 years at 21 days = 48,300, remaining 13.2986 years at 30 days = 183,521.10, total 231,821.10. Admin's manual calculation arrived at different figure due to misapplication of the tiered formula.

findings.group_description: System does not include leave accrual for the departure month when employee departs mid-month under monthly accrual policy. This is standard system behaviour: monthly accrual policies grant leave days only at end of month, so incomplete months are not accrued. Admin must either use conditional accrual policy (daily accrual) or manually adjust EOS balance.
findings.issue_explanation: Employee departed 17/10/2025 (mid-month). October leave balance was not included in EOS calculation because the leave policy uses monthly accrual, which only grants leave days after the month is completed. Since the employee did not complete October, no leave days were earned for that month. Support clarified this is standard system behaviour across all modules.
findings.limitation_statement: Monthly accrual policies do not prorate or include partial month leave balances for mid-month departures. The system cannot automatically include incomplete month accrual under monthly accrual policy configuration.
findings.gap_statement: System lacks automatic handling of partial month leave accrual for mid-month departures. Workaround requires manual adjustment in EOS section or switching to conditional accrual policy.

findings.group_description: The system's handling of leap year days (specifically February 29th) in gratuity calculation is not transparent to users. This causes confusion about whether the system correctly includes the extra day when calculating total service duration, leading to discrepancies between user manual calculations and system-generated amounts.
findings.issue_explanation: Ticket TSSD-1625 reports that a client calculated 913 days of service (including Feb 29, 2024) resulting in gratuity of AED 14,708.05, while the platform showed 912 days and AED 14,691.95. Investigation revealed the system actually calculated 14,700 correctly, but the client manually edited it. The core issue is lack of transparency about leap year day inclusion in the calculation methodology.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not provide transparent documentation or UI feedback about how leap year days are included in service duration calculations, making it unclear to users whether the calculation is correct.
findings.gap_statement: There is a need for clear, user-facing explanation of how leap years and February 29th are handled in gratuity calculation methodology.

findings.group_description: The system's methodology for counting service days is ambiguous regarding whether the departure date itself counts as a working day. This ambiguity causes users to arrive at different day counts (92 vs 93 days in the reported case) and consequently different gratuity amounts.
findings.issue_explanation: Ticket TSSD-1625 shows confusion about whether the departure date (April 2, 2024) should be counted as the last working day. The client initially calculated 93 days (Jan 31 + Feb 29 + March 31 + April 2), but the system showed 92 days. The team confirmed that the departure date IS counted as the last working day, but this rule was not clearly communicated to the user.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not clearly communicate or document the rule that the departure date counts as the last working day in service duration calculation.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation is needed to clarify the departure date inclusion rule in service duration counting for gratuity calculations.

findings.group_description: The system allows users to manually edit gratuity amounts without validation or warning, which can override the system's calculated value. In the reported case, the client manually changed the system-calculated amount of AED 14,700 to AED 14,691.95, creating confusion about which value was correct.
findings.issue_explanation: Ticket TSSD-1625 reveals that the system calculated gratuity as AED 14,700, but the client manually edited it to AED 14,691.95. This manual override capability, combined with lack of validation, allowed an incorrect value to be saved without system feedback or audit trail visibility.
findings.limitation_statement: The system allows manual editing of calculated gratuity amounts without validation, warning, or clear indication that the value has been overridden from the system calculation.
findings.gap_statement: There is a need for validation, warning dialogs, or audit trails when users manually edit system-calculated gratuity amounts.

findings.group_description: The system divides total service days by 365 to calculate years of service for gratuity computation, but this methodology is not transparent to users. Users may not understand that leap years are implicitly handled through this division method, leading to confusion about calculation accuracy.
findings.issue_explanation: Ticket TSSD-1625 shows the calculation: 913 days / 365 = 2.501 years (client) vs 912 days / 365 = 2.498 years (system). The methodology of dividing by a fixed 365 days is not documented, making it unclear to users how the system converts service days to years.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not document or explain the methodology of dividing total service days by 365 to calculate years of service, making the calculation logic opaque to users.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation is needed to explain the service duration calculation methodology: how total days are divided by 365 to determine years of service for gratuity brackets.

findings.group_description: The system calculates gratuity for partial years above 5 years of service using a specific methodology that differs from manual calculation approaches. The platform counts incomplete final years in days, then divides by 366 (for leap years) or 365 (for non-leap years) to derive the year fraction, which is not transparently communicated to users.
findings.issue_explanation: Client calculated 1434 days for the period over 5 years, but the system calculated 1437 days. The discrepancy arose because the system counts the incomplete final year (339 days from 26/6/2024 to 28/6/2024, accounting for leap year 2024) and divides by 366, yielding 0.926 years. The client's manual approach did not account for this leap year adjustment methodology.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform's gratuity calculation logic for partial years and leap year handling is not transparently documented or explained within the UI, leading to user confusion about the calculation basis.
findings.gap_statement: There is no clear, user-facing documentation or UI explanation showing how the system calculates service duration for partial years, when to use divisor 365 vs 366, or worked examples demonstrating the calculation methodology.

findings.group_description: The system automatically selects divisor 366 when a service period includes a leap year and divisor 365 otherwise, but this logic is not documented or visible to users. This creates confusion when users manually calculate gratuity and receive different results.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket shows that for the period 26/6/2024 to 28/6/2024 (which includes leap year 2024), the system used divisor 366 to convert 339 days to years (339/366 = 0.926 years). The client's manual calculation did not apply this leap year adjustment, resulting in a 30 AED difference in the final gratuity amount.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not expose or explain the leap year divisor selection logic to users, making it impossible for them to replicate or verify the calculation manually.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation is needed explaining when the system uses 366 vs 365 as the divisor for partial year calculations, including the criteria for determining leap year inclusion.

findings.group_description: The gratuity calculation involves multiple tiers (21 days per year for first 5 years, 30 days per year above 5 years) and complex service duration segmentation, but the system does not provide a breakdown or explanation of how these tiers are applied. Users cannot see the intermediate calculation steps.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket demonstrates a multi-step calculation: (1) segment service into periods (first 5 years, then remaining years), (2) count days for incomplete final year, (3) convert to years using leap-year-aware divisor, (4) apply tier-specific multipliers (21 or 30 days per year), (5) sum the results. None of these steps are visible or explained in the system output.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not display the calculation breakdown, service period segmentation, or the rationale for tier selection, making it difficult for users to understand or audit the gratuity amount.
findings.gap_statement: A detailed calculation breakdown or explanation feature is needed to show users how their gratuity was calculated, including service period segments, day counts, year fractions, and tier applications.

findings.group_description: The platform uses a fixed divisor of 30 days to calculate daily wage (Basic Salary / 30), which cannot be modified via configuration. This prevents organizations that require alternative daily wage formulas, such as (Basic Salary × 12 / 365), from customizing their gratuity calculations.
findings.issue_explanation: In ticket TSSD-2043, the client expected daily wage to be calculated as (Basic × 12 / 365) = AED 246.57, but the platform uses a hardcoded formula (Basic / 30) = AED 250. Support confirmed that the 30-day divisor is fixed and cannot be modified by 'daily wage calculation' settings in the configuration page. This is the current and expected behavior.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform cannot support alternative daily wage calculation formulas beyond the fixed (Basic Salary / 30) divisor. Daily wage calculation settings in configuration do not affect the gratuity calculation method.
findings.gap_statement: The platform lacks flexibility to accommodate different organizational daily wage calculation methodologies in gratuity calculations.

findings.group_description: The gratuity calculation for an employee showed a discrepancy in days worked count: the system calculated 623 days instead of the expected 622 days (after deducting 10 days unpaid leave from 632 total working days). This one-day difference propagated through the tenure calculation and resulted in a higher gratuity amount.
findings.issue_explanation: In ticket TSSD-2043, the admin calculated: 107 + 365 + 160 = 632 days - 10 days unpaid leave = 622 days. However, the platform captured 623 days, leading to 623/366 = 1.702 years instead of the expected 622/366 = 1.699 years. This resulted in gratuity of AED 8,936.48 instead of AED 8,922.13.

findings.group_description: The gratuity calculation method is hardcoded and does not support customization of daily wage formulas. Organizations with specific calculation requirements (e.g., Basic × 12 / 365 instead of Basic / 30) cannot adjust the system to match their policies.
findings.issue_explanation: Ticket TSSD-2043 reveals that the client's gratuity policy uses the formula (Basic × 12 / 365) × 21 days per year × years of service, but the platform enforces (Basic / 30) × 21 days per year × years of service. Support confirmed this is the current and expected behavior, and no configuration option exists to change it.
findings.limitation_statement: The gratuity calculation method cannot be customized to support alternative daily wage formulas. The system does not provide configuration options to modify the daily wage divisor or calculation methodology.
findings.gap_statement: The platform lacks support for flexible gratuity calculation methodologies that different organizations may require.

findings.group_description: Leave salary calculations use a fixed divisor from policy configuration rather than adapting to actual calendar days in the month. When a leave policy is configured with a specific day divisor (e.g., 30 days), the system applies that divisor regardless of whether the month has 31 days, resulting in discrepancies between expected and actual leave salary amounts.
findings.issue_explanation: Employee Edison Maglanag reported that leave salary for October should be divided by 31 (calendar days) but the system divided by 30, resulting in 2940 SAR instead of expected 2988 SAR. Support clarified that the system calculates leave salary based on the daily rate configuration in the leave policy, not based on actual calendar days.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform's leave salary calculation is rigidly tied to predefined policy configurations and does not flexibly adapt to varying month lengths or specific employee scenarios.
findings.gap_statement: There is no mechanism for the system to automatically adjust the daily wage divisor based on actual calendar days in the month; the divisor is fixed at policy configuration time.

findings.group_description: Users may misunderstand how leave salary calculations work, expecting the system to automatically adjust for calendar realities (e.g., 31 days in October) when in fact the system applies a fixed divisor from policy configuration. This creates a gap between user expectations and actual system behavior.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket demonstrates a case where the user believed the daily wage should be divided by 31 (calendar days for October) but the system was dividing by 30 (the configured policy divisor). Support resolved this by explaining that leave salary is calculated based on the daily rate configuration in the leave policy, not calendar days.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not provide transparent, real-time feedback about which divisor will be applied to leave salary calculations, leading to user confusion.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation and UI guidance are insufficient to explain how daily wage divisor configuration in leave policies affects leave salary calculations, particularly when month length varies.

findings.group_description: When leave encashment is configured to use 'working days' calculation method, the daily wage rate fluctuates based on the number of working days in each month. This causes cumulative leave salary accrual amounts to vary unpredictably across months with different working day counts, making month-to-month comparisons inconsistent.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket reports that an employee's cumulative leave salary accrual jumped from an expected AED 31,610.68 to AED 34,312 in February due to the daily wage calculator being set to 'working days' for leave encashment. February had 20 working days, causing the daily wage to recalculate and produce a different accrual amount than expected when added to the prior month's balance.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot maintain a stable daily wage rate across months when 'working days' is selected for leave encashment calculations. The daily wage denominator changes monthly based on working day counts, making cumulative accrual amounts inconsistent.
findings.gap_statement: The platform lacks a straightforward mechanism to ensure consistent daily wage calculations across months with varying working day counts. Users need clearer guidance on how configuration choices (working days vs custom days) impact accrual reporting consistency.

findings.group_description: Users are unclear about how the daily wage calculator's leave encashment settings directly impact cumulative leave salary accrual reporting. The relationship between the 'working days' vs 'custom days' configuration choice and month-to-month accrual consistency is not well documented or communicated.
findings.issue_explanation: The client questioned why the February cumulative leave salary accrual differed from their manual calculation expectation. The support response indicated the system is working as configured, but the client needed to understand that selecting 'working days' for leave encashment causes daily wage to vary by month, directly affecting accrual amounts.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation does not clearly explain how the leave encashment calculation method (working days vs custom days) in the daily wage calculator affects cumulative accrual amounts across months with different working day counts.

findings.group_description: The system maintains separate daily wage configurations for leave salary calculations and salary proration, each with independent divisors (e.g., 30 days vs 30.42 days). This causes calculation mismatches when clients expect unified daily wage formulas across both scenarios.
findings.issue_explanation: Ticket TSSD-2321 documents a case where leave salary policy uses a 30-day divisor while salary proration uses 30.42 days. Client expected (7000/30.42)*21 = 4,832.35 but system calculated 4,666.67 using the leave salary policy's 30-day divisor. The root cause is that leave salary daily wage and salary proration daily wage are configured independently and do not share a unified formula.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot automatically align leave salary and salary proration daily wage calculations without manual configuration of both settings independently.
findings.gap_statement: The platform lacks a unified daily wage calculation method that consistently applies across leave salary and salary proration scenarios, requiring clients to manually configure and maintain separate divisor settings.

findings.group_description: When leave salary policy and salary proration use different divisors, the resulting prorated amounts diverge from client expectations. This creates confusion about which formula is being applied and why calculations do not match manual computations.
findings.issue_explanation: In TSSD-2321, the client configured leave salary policy with a 30-day divisor but salary proration with 30.42 days. When an employee took 10 days leave in July, the system deducted (7000/30)*10 = 2,333.33, leaving a prorated amount of 4,666.67. The client expected the proration to use the 30.42-day divisor, yielding 4,832.35. The system applied the leave salary policy divisor instead of the salary proration divisor.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot apply the salary proration daily wage formula to leave salary calculations; each configuration operates independently.
findings.gap_statement: There is no mechanism to enforce consistent daily wage divisors across leave salary and salary proration, or to automatically synchronize these configurations.

findings.group_description: Users may misinterpret proration calculations when an employee's work week has all 7 days configured as working days with no weekends. The system correctly calculates based on work week configuration, but this can appear incorrect if the user expects weekend exclusions.
findings.issue_explanation: In ticket TSSD-4292, the customer reported that salary proration was not calculating based on working days as expected. Investigation revealed the system was calculating correctly: the employee (Melanie Bongalos) was assigned to NVK Operations work week, which has all 7 days configured as working days with no weekends, resulting in 31 working days for the full month.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot override work week-based calculation logic. Proration is entirely dependent on the work week configuration assigned to the employee, and there is no way to manually adjust working days for proration purposes.

findings.group_description: Salary proration calculations depend entirely on the employee's assigned work week configuration. If a work week has all days marked as working days, the full month will be counted as working days, which may not match user expectations.
findings.issue_explanation: Ticket TSSD-4292 demonstrates that proration logic is not independent of work week setup. The system calculates working days based on which days are marked as working days in the assigned work week policy. For NVK Operations (all 7 days working), this results in 31 working days per month.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot calculate proration independently of work week configuration. Users must ensure their work week policies correctly reflect their intended working days (including weekend configuration) before proration will calculate as expected.

findings.group_description: When an employee's departure date is set in the future (e.g., Nov 28th) but payroll is processed earlier (e.g., Nov 27th), the system fails to prorate the salary and displays the full monthly amount instead. This causes incorrect salary calculations for offboarded employees with future-dated departure times.
findings.issue_explanation: The salary proration logic in the daily wage calculator contains a date-comparison bug. The system correctly prorates salaries when the departure date is in the past relative to payroll processing, but fails to prorate when the departure date is in the future. This was confirmed in the Daria Demo Account with employee Ahmed Khan (offboarded Nov 28th, payroll processed Nov 27th), where the full November salary was shown instead of the prorated amount (AED 10,500 based on 15 days × daily rate of AED 700).
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot correctly prorate salaries for employees with future departure dates during payroll processing. Proration only functions when the departure date has already passed.
findings.gap_statement: The daily wage calculator lacks robust date-sensitive proration logic that handles dynamic scenarios where payroll processing occurs before the employee's departure date.

findings.group_description: The proration calculation exhibits inconsistent behavior based on whether the departure date is relative to the payroll processing date. Past departure dates trigger proration correctly; future departure dates do not, indicating a conditional logic error in the date comparison mechanism.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents that the system's proration behavior is time-dependent: 'if the departure day is in the past, the salary is prorated; if the departure day is in the future, the salary is not prorated.' This asymmetry indicates a logic error where the system uses a date comparison condition that only triggers proration for past dates, rather than applying proration based on the departure date itself regardless of processing timing.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot apply consistent proration logic across different temporal scenarios (past vs. future departure dates relative to payroll processing).
findings.gap_statement: The daily wage calculator requires enhanced date-handling logic to ensure proration applies uniformly based on departure date, independent of when payroll is processed.

findings.group_description: When an unpaid leave transaction is deleted to recalculate after a daily wage calculation change, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. This results in incorrect payroll deductions being applied to the employee.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket describes a scenario where an approved unpaid leave request with a submitted transaction is modified by changing the daily wage calculation, then the transaction is deleted to recalculate. Instead of cleanly recalculating, the system generates two separate deductions for the same leave request.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot reliably recalculate unpaid leave deductions when the daily wage calculation basis changes without creating duplicate deduction entries.

findings.group_description: When an unpaid leave request is deleted entirely, the associated payroll deduction persists in the system and is not automatically removed. This creates orphaned deductions that remain on payroll records even though the leave request no longer exists.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents that after deleting an unpaid leave request, the unpaid leave deduction still appears in payroll deductions. This indicates a synchronization failure between the leave management module and the payroll deduction module.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not automatically remove payroll deductions when their associated unpaid leave requests are deleted.
findings.gap_statement: There is a gap in leave-to-payroll synchronization logic that should automatically reconcile and remove orphaned deductions when leave requests are removed.

findings.group_description: Attempting to move an unpaid leave request from approved status back to pending or accepted status does not trigger removal or recalculation of associated payroll deductions. The deductions remain unchanged despite the leave status change.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket indicates that changing the leave request status (moving from approved to pending/accepted) does not resolve the duplicate deduction issue, suggesting that status changes do not trigger payroll deduction synchronization.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not synchronize payroll deductions when unpaid leave request status is changed.

findings.group_description: When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation (Payroll side) and the number of leave days (HR/Time Off side) become out of sync. This results in incorrect unpaid leave deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected by the system.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents a case where employee 'Wadah Mohammad' applied for unpaid leave from 15 Apr 2025 to 15 Oct 2025. In July 2025, the expected deduction was 3,700 AED (full month salary), but the platform calculated 3,557.69 AED. Investigation revealed that two public holidays were added on 22 July and 25 June (after the leave request was created). The daily wage was initially calculated with 26 working days (1 PH), but when the second PH was added, the leave days count was reduced to 25 days. The daily wage remained locked at the old calculation (3,700/26), resulting in: 3,700/26 × 25 = 3,557.69 AED instead of the full month salary.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot recalculate unpaid leave deductions retroactively when public holidays are added after the leave request has been processed. The daily wage calculation is locked at the time of initial processing and does not update when configuration changes occur mid-cycle.
findings.gap_statement: The Time Off module does not send complete leave request details to the Payroll module at calculation time, preventing the Payroll module from determining the correct number of working days when public holiday configurations change after leave request creation.

findings.group_description: The Time Off and Payroll modules operate independently without real-time data synchronization. When the Time Off module updates leave day counts based on new public holiday configurations, the Payroll module's daily wage calculation is not automatically updated, creating data inconsistency.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket states: 'The problem is not in ph in general it's because they added a new PH recently so that's why it caused the mismatch in number of days.' The team confirmed that 'the only one we have is to add manual deduction, or to open all previous cycles until the time of creation of this leave request.' The root cause analysis indicates: 'it seems that their is one PH was added late so it causing some difference between the number created from Payroll side (Daily wage) and and from HR (Number of leave days).' The team is working on a long-term fix: 'we can't identify the exact root cause, and we also can't reproduce it. The team is currently working on a long-term fix where the Time Off module will send all leave request details to the Payroll module.'
findings.limitation_statement: The current system architecture does not support bidirectional communication between Time Off and Payroll modules. Once a daily wage calculation is performed, it remains static even if the underlying configuration (public holidays, working days) changes.
findings.gap_statement: A feature enhancement is needed where the Time Off module sends complete leave request details (including final working days count) to the Payroll module at the time of calculation, ensuring both modules use consistent data for deduction calculations.

findings.group_description: The system does not provide a mechanism to automatically recalculate or correct unpaid leave deductions after they have been initially calculated, even when the underlying configuration data changes. Manual intervention is required.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents that 'Unfortunately we cant change the main deduction now, but we can add a manual deduction to fix the issue.' When asked about alternative solutions, the support team confirmed: 'the only available solutions are either applying a manual deduction or reopening previous cycles.' The customer explicitly stated: 'The customer doesn't want to make any manual adjustments.' However, no automated correction mechanism exists.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot retroactively recalculate unpaid leave deductions once they have been processed. The only available workarounds are manual deduction entry or reopening entire payroll cycles, neither of which is practical for customers who have already processed payroll.
findings.gap_statement: There is no automated mechanism to detect and correct deduction inconsistencies when configuration changes (such as public holiday additions) occur after leave request processing.

findings.group_description: The unpaid leave deduction calculation uses a configured custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) rather than calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that exceed the employee's monthly salary. This creates user confusion when the calculated deduction does not match expected salary amounts.
findings.issue_explanation: Ticket TSSD-4368 documents an employee with a 4,300 AED monthly salary who took 60 days unpaid leave (June 2 - July 31). The system calculated a July deduction of 4,381.99 AED using the formula: daily wage = 4300/30.42 = 141.35, then 141.35 × 31 days = 4,381.99. The user expected the deduction to be exactly 4,300 AED (the full monthly salary) to bring the payout to zero, but the system's divisor configuration produced an 81.99 AED overage.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot automatically cap unpaid leave deductions at the monthly salary amount. Deductions calculated using the configured custom days divisor may exceed the employee's monthly salary, requiring manual adjustment to reconcile.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks transparent, user-friendly documentation explaining why unpaid leave deductions calculated using custom day divisors may not equal the monthly salary, and does not provide automatic reconciliation when deductions exceed expected amounts.

findings.group_description: The unpaid leave policy setting allows configuration of the daily wage divisor (custom days vs calendar days). The choice of divisor directly impacts the calculated deduction amount, and switching divisors can produce significantly different results for the same leave period.
findings.issue_explanation: TSSD-4368 reveals that the unpaid leave policy uses a 30.42 custom days divisor instead of calendar days. The support response confirms: 'To calculate the unpaid deduction, the system follows the daily wage configured in the Unpaid leave policy setting (Divide by custom days = 30.42 not calendar days).' This configuration choice is the root cause of the deduction amount mismatch.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not provide a way to preview or compare deduction amounts under different divisor configurations before applying them to payroll.
findings.gap_statement: There is no built-in validation or warning when unpaid leave deductions calculated with the configured divisor will exceed the employee's monthly salary.

findings.group_description: The remarks field displays an incorrect number of days (31) for February unpaid leave deductions when the system is configured for calendar days. This creates a discrepancy between what users see in the remarks and the actual calendar days used in the calculation, even though the underlying deduction amount is mathematically correct.
findings.issue_explanation: For February with 29 days, the remarks field shows a daily rate of 925.81 (calculated as 28,700/31) instead of 989.66 (28,700/29). The actual deduction of 16,824.14 is correct (989.66 × 17 unpaid days), but the remarks reference the wrong divisor (31 days instead of 29).
findings.limitation_statement: The platform cannot dynamically display the correct number of calendar days in the remarks field for months with fewer than 31 days, particularly February in leap years.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks a mechanism to automatically detect and display the actual number of days in each month within the remarks field, causing a mismatch between displayed daily rate and actual calculation basis.

findings.group_description: Global unpaid leave daily rate configuration automatically overrides policy-level calculation settings. Users configure leave policies to use basic salary divided by working days, but the system applies a global daily rate instead, resulting in deductions calculated from gross salary rather than the configured basic salary component.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents that a global daily rate configuration exists for unpaid leaves which takes precedence over individual leave policy settings. When an employee applied for 10 days unpaid leave, the deduction was calculated using gross salary (7500/25 = 300) instead of the configured basic salary (4500/25 = 180). The dev team confirmed this is expected behaviour due to the global configuration override mechanism.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform cannot allow policy-level customization of unpaid leave deduction calculations when a global daily rate configuration exists. Users cannot override the global setting at the policy level.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks transparent configuration hierarchy documentation and user controls to manage the precedence between global and policy-level settings. There is no clear visibility into which configuration level takes precedence, and no mechanism to customize leave deduction calculations at the policy level when global settings exist.

findings.group_description: The system has a hidden configuration hierarchy where global unpaid leave settings override policy-specific calculation methods, but this precedence is not clearly communicated to users. Users expect policy-level settings to control deduction calculations but discover the global configuration takes precedence only after encountering incorrect deductions.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket reveals that users configured unpaid leave policies with specific calculation methods (basic salary / working days) but the system applied a global daily rate configuration instead. The dev team confirmed this is expected behaviour, indicating the hierarchy exists but is not transparent to end users. This creates a support burden as users must investigate why their policy settings are not being applied.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not provide transparent visibility into the configuration hierarchy that determines which settings take precedence for unpaid leave deduction calculations.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation and UI guidance are needed to explain the configuration hierarchy and help users understand where to find and modify the global daily rate configuration that overrides policy-level settings.

findings.group_description: Unpaid leave deductions are calculated using an unexpected salary component (gross salary instead of basic salary) and divisor (calendar days or different working days count instead of configured working days). Multiple employees experienced incorrect deduction amounts that did not match their policy configuration.
findings.issue_explanation: Two employees (SHOAIB ZADA and MOHAMMED NAYEEM SALEEM BASHA) had unpaid leave deductions calculated incorrectly. For the first employee on a 7-day work week with 5 public holidays, the system calculated 7500/25 = 300 (using gross salary) instead of 4500/25 = 180 (using basic salary as configured). The policy was set to Basic Salary / Working Days but the global daily rate configuration overrode this setting.
findings.limitation_statement: The system applies a global daily rate configuration for unpaid leaves that cannot be overridden at the policy level, preventing accurate deductions based on policy-specific salary components and working day calculations.
findings.gap_statement: Users need a way to verify which configuration is being applied to their unpaid leave deductions and to customize calculations at the policy level when the global setting does not match their requirements.

findings.group_description: The system displays the daily rate from the payroll processing month instead of the leave occurrence month, causing user confusion. Although the deduction amount is calculated correctly, the displayed daily rate does not match the month when the leave actually occurred.
findings.issue_explanation: In ticket TSSD-1807, an unpaid leave deduction for April showed a daily rate of 173.91 (May's rate) instead of 235.29 (April's rate). The system recalculates the daily rate based on the payroll month rather than storing the initially calculated rate from the leave occurrence month. The actual deduction amount (2,117.65) was correct, but the displayed daily rate caused confusion.
findings.limitation_statement: The system recalculates daily rates based on the payroll processing month instead of storing and displaying the rate from the original leave occurrence month.
findings.gap_statement: There is a need for a consistent daily rate display mechanism that preserves the initially calculated rate at the time of leave request, ensuring transparency and accuracy in payroll deduction representations.

findings.group_description: Users need clear documentation on the daily rate calculation formula and how working days are determined, including the treatment of public holidays. The formula (Basic + Allowances / Working Days) must be explicitly documented with examples.
findings.issue_explanation: Ticket TSSD-1807 demonstrates confusion about the daily wage calculation formula. The correct formula is (Basic + Allowances) / Working Days, where working days exclude public holidays. For April with 22 calendar days minus 5 Eid holiday days = 17 working days, the daily rate should be 4000/17 = 235.29. This calculation method was not immediately clear to the customer.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation must explicitly clarify the daily wage calculation formula, the definition of working days (calendar days minus public holidays), and provide worked examples showing how different months with varying public holidays affect the daily rate.

troubleshooting.group_description: When automated salary proration based on working days is not available, a manual workaround exists using a combination of unpaid leaves and overtime tracking. This requires per-employee manual configuration and tracking.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Use a mix of unpaid leaves and overtime policies, configured and tracked separately for each employee. This allows manual adjustment of salary based on actual working days, but requires individual employee setup and ongoing manual management.

troubleshooting.group_description: User observes formula mismatch between leave policy and payroll settings. Root cause: payroll-side daily wage calculator configuration takes precedence over leave policy formula.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: To determine which formula is actually being applied for unpaid leave deductions: (1) Check the daily wage calculator configuration in Settings > Payroll > Daily Wage Calculation. (2) Verify the salary component selection (Basic Only vs Basic + Allowances) and calculation basis (calendar days, working days, or custom days). (3) Understand that the greyed-out formula in leave policy indicates it is being overridden by payroll settings. (4) The formula configured in payroll settings will be used for unpaid leave deductions, not the leave policy formula.

troubleshooting.group_description: Unpaid leave deductions show incorrect amounts after salary configuration changes. The system calculated deductions based on previous salary configuration instead of the current one.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Delete the leave request and create it again if the deduction has not been processed yet. This forces the system to recalculate the deduction using the current salary configuration. Note: This workaround only works before the deduction is processed into payroll. The development team has implemented a fix to ensure unpaid leave deductions update automatically when new salary configurations are created.

troubleshooting.group_description: When gratuity calculations appear incorrect or lower than expected, verify the calculation against MOHRE (Ministry of Human Resources) standards to confirm the correct amount.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Contact MOHRE to verify the correct gratuity calculation. In the reported case, MOHRE confirmed the correct gratuity should be AED 10,494.24 (using 366 days for 2024), not AED 10,476.98 (using 365 days). This verification can help identify whether the system calculation is incorrect due to leap year handling.

troubleshooting.group_description: When End of Service pro-rated amounts appear incorrect, users should verify the calculation manually and escalate to the development team for investigation.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Double-check the pro-rated amount calculation by manually computing the daily wage based on the configured formula (basic + allowances / 30) and the departure date. If discrepancies persist, escalate the ticket to the development team for investigation and resolution.

troubleshooting.group_description: Admin questioned why October leave balance was not included in EOS for mid-month departure. System uses monthly accrual policy which only grants leave at end of month.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Two options: (1) Switch leave policy to conditional accrual policy, which grants leave days daily instead of monthly, allowing partial month accrual. (2) Manually adjust the leave balance in the EOS section after departure to account for incomplete month accrual.

troubleshooting.group_description: Admin questioned discrepancy between system gratuity calculation and manual calculation. Support provided detailed breakdown of correct calculation methodology.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Verify gratuity calculation by: (1) Confirm hire date and departure date are correct. (2) Calculate service duration: split into completed years and remaining days. (3) Apply tiered formula: 21 days per year for first 5 years, 30 days per year for years above 5. (4) For incomplete years, divide remaining days by 365 to get partial year count. (5) Multiply daily wage by days and year count for each tier. (6) Sum all tiers for total gratuity.

troubleshooting.group_description: Users confused about whether the departure date counts as a working day in service duration calculation. This causes discrepancies between manual and system calculations.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Confirm with the system team that the departure date IS counted as the last working day of the employee. When calculating service days, include the departure date in the total count. For example, for departure on April 2, 2024, count Jan 31 + Feb 29 + March 31 + April 2 = 93 days (not 92 days).

troubleshooting.group_description: Users may manually edit gratuity amounts without realizing the system has already calculated a value. This can introduce errors if the manual edit is based on incomplete understanding of the calculation methodology.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Before editing a gratuity amount manually, verify the system-calculated amount by reviewing the calculation breakdown (basic salary, daily wage, service duration in years, applicable gratuity bracket). If the system amount appears incorrect, investigate the service day count and departure date inclusion rule rather than immediately overriding the value.

troubleshooting.group_description: When a client's manual gratuity calculation differs from the system's result, the issue is typically due to misunderstanding how the system handles partial years and leap years, not a calculation error.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: To verify gratuity calculations: (1) Break down service duration into completed years and remaining days (e.g., 8 years 11 months 3 days). (2) For the incomplete final year, count days month-by-month accounting for leap years. (3) Convert incomplete years to a fraction by dividing days by 366 (if leap year included) or 365 (if not). (4) Apply the correct tier multiplier: 21 days per year for first 5 years of service, 30 days per year for service above 5 years. (5) Calculate daily wage as basic salary divided by 30. (6) Sum the tier-specific amounts. If the result matches the system output, the calculation is correct.

troubleshooting.group_description: When gratuity amounts appear incorrect, verify the days worked calculation by breaking down the components: total working days, unpaid leave deductions, and the resulting days used in tenure calculation.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Manually verify the days worked calculation by summing the working day periods and subtracting unpaid leave days. Cross-check the platform's calculated days against your manual breakdown to identify discrepancies. If a one-day variance exists, review the date range logic and public holiday handling.

troubleshooting.group_description: If gratuity calculations do not match expected amounts based on alternative daily wage formulas (e.g., Basic × 12 / 365), understand that the platform uses a fixed (Basic / 30) divisor that cannot be modified.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Acknowledge that the platform uses a fixed daily wage calculation of (Basic Salary / 30). If your organization requires a different formula such as (Basic × 12 / 365), document this as a known limitation and adjust your expected gratuity amounts accordingly. No configuration option exists to change this behavior.

troubleshooting.group_description: When leave salary calculations appear incorrect, the root cause is often the daily rate divisor configured in the leave policy. Users should verify that the policy configuration matches their expectations.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Check the daily rate configuration in the leave policy. The system calculates leave salary based on the daily rate divisor set in the policy configuration, not based on actual calendar days. Verify that the policy divisor (e.g., 30 or 31 days) matches your intended calculation method. If the divisor is incorrect, update the leave policy configuration to use the correct divisor.

troubleshooting.group_description: When cumulative leave salary accrual amounts fluctuate unexpectedly across months, the root cause is often the 'working days' setting in leave encashment configuration. Switching to 'custom days' setting stabilizes the daily wage calculation.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Navigate to the daily wage calculator leave encashment settings. If the current setting is 'working days', change it to 'custom days' to maintain a consistent daily wage rate across all months, regardless of the number of working days in each month.

troubleshooting.group_description: When leave salary calculations do not match salary proration calculations, verify that both the leave salary policy and salary proration daily wage settings use the same divisor (e.g., both 30 days or both 30.42 days).
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Configure the leave salary policy divisor to match the salary proration divisor. In the example from TSSD-2321, if salary proration is set to 30.42 days, ensure the leave salary policy is also configured with 30.42 days. This requires manual alignment of both settings in Settings > Payroll > Daily Wage Calculation and Settings > Leaves > Leave Policies.

troubleshooting.group_description: When proration appears to be calculating incorrectly based on working days, the root cause is typically the employee's assigned work week configuration.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Verify the employee's assigned work week configuration. Check that the work week policy has the correct working days and weekend configuration. If all 7 days are marked as working days (as in NVK Operations), the full month will be counted as working days, which is correct behavior. Confirm the daily wage setting is enabled and the work week is properly assigned to the employee.

troubleshooting.group_description: The salary proration bug for future departure dates was escalated to the development team and subsequently fixed. The issue was confirmed as a bug through replication in the demo account and resolved through development team intervention.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: The development team fixed the underlying calculation logic error. The ticket status changed to 'Resolved' after the fix was deployed. Users should verify that salary proration now works correctly for both past and future departure dates by checking the active payroll cycle to confirm prorated salary is calculated as of the departure date.

troubleshooting.group_description: When unpaid leave deductions persist after deleting the leave request or changing the daily wage calculation, manual intervention is required to remove the orphaned or duplicate deductions from the payroll system.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: After deleting an unpaid leave request or recalculating due to a daily wage change, manually verify payroll deductions and remove any orphaned or duplicate entries that were not automatically cleaned up by the system. This may require backend intervention or manual payroll adjustment.

troubleshooting.group_description: When unpaid leave deductions are calculated incorrectly due to public holiday timing mismatches, the system cannot automatically recalculate. The documented workaround is to manually add a deduction entry to compensate for the difference.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Create a manual deduction to fix the issue. The support team stated: 'Unfortunately we cant change the main deduction now, but we can add a manual deduction to fix the issue.' Calculate the difference between the expected full month salary deduction and the actual deduction calculated by the system, then add this difference as a manual deduction entry in the payroll system.

troubleshooting.group_description: An alternative workaround to manual deduction is to reopen previous payroll cycles to allow recalculation of deductions. However, this is not practical for customers who have already processed and finalized payroll.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Reopen all previous cycles until the time of creation of the leave request to allow the system to recalculate deductions with updated public holiday configurations. The support team noted: 'or to open all previous cycles until the time of creation of this leave request (Which offcourse wont be applicable).' This solution is impractical because it requires reverting completed payroll processing.

troubleshooting.group_description: User is confused about why unpaid leave deduction amount does not match expected monthly salary. Root cause is the daily wage divisor configured in the unpaid leave policy.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Verify the unpaid leave policy configuration by navigating to Settings > Leaves > Unpaid Leave option > calculation method > day calculation type. Confirm whether the policy uses custom days (e.g., 30.42) or calendar days. If using custom days divisor, calculate expected deduction as: (monthly salary / custom days divisor) × number of leave days in the month. If the deduction exceeds the monthly salary, this is expected behavior based on the configured divisor.

troubleshooting.group_description: When unpaid leave deduction calculated by the system exceeds the employee's monthly salary due to the configured divisor, manual adjustment is required to reconcile the payroll.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: If the unpaid leave deduction amount exceeds the monthly salary and needs to be reconciled to zero payout, add a manual adjustment (addition) to the payroll to offset the overage. In the example from TSSD-4368, the payroll representative added 81.99 AED as a manual addition to balance the deduction of 4,381.99 AED against the monthly salary of 4,300 AED.

troubleshooting.group_description: When remarks show an incorrect daily rate for unpaid leave deductions, users should verify the actual deduction amount rather than relying on the remarks field, as the backend calculation uses the correct calendar days.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Double-check the actual deduction amount (unpaid days × correct daily rate) against the payroll transaction. The calculation is accurate even if the remarks display is incorrect. For February, verify that the daily rate used is based on 29 days, not 31 days, by dividing the monthly salary by 29 and multiplying by the number of unpaid days.

troubleshooting.group_description: When unpaid leave deductions appear incorrect or do not match policy-level settings, the issue is likely caused by a global daily rate configuration that overrides policy-specific calculations.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Check the global daily rate configuration for unpaid leaves. The dev team confirmed that a global daily rate configuration exists and takes precedence over policy-level calculation methods. Verify the global settings are correct before investigating policy-level configurations. If the global setting does not match your requirements, contact support to adjust the global configuration.

troubleshooting.group_description: The system was updated to store the initially calculated daily rate at the time of leave request and display that stored value instead of recalculating it based on the current payroll month.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: A fix was deployed which stores the initially calculated daily rate when the leave deduction is created. The system now displays the stored daily rate on the 'daily rate' label instead of recalculating it every time, preventing the display of rates from the wrong payroll month.

glossary.definition: The number of business days in a period, calculated as: Total Days - Weekend Days - Public Holidays. The count depends on when public holidays are configured. If public holidays are added after payroll calculation, the working days count used by the Time Off module may differ from the count used by the Payroll module.

The process of calculating a partial salary amount based on the number of days an employee worked during a payroll period. For offboarded employees, proration is calculated from the start of the payroll cycle to the departure date. Example: Employee with AED 21,000 monthly salary departing on day 15 of a 30-day month receives AED 10,500 (21,000 ÷ 30 × 15).
Salary calculated proportionally based on actual days worked relative to the standard working days per month, without manual adjustments.

A formula displayed in the leave policy interface that is disabled (non-editable) because it has been overridden by the daily wage calculator configured in payroll settings. The greyed-out display indicates the formula is not valid for the current configuration and will not be used for calculations.

The calculated daily salary rate used for unpaid leave deductions, computed as: Basic Salary + Allowances / Working Days. Working days exclude weekends and public holidays. This value is locked at the time of initial calculation and does not update if public holidays are added later.

The component of employee salary used in daily wage calculations. Options include 'Basic Only' (basic salary only) or 'Basic + Allowances' (basic salary plus allowances). The selected component determines which salary elements are included in the daily wage calculation.
The daily wage calculated by dividing total salary by 30.41 (standard days in month for calculation purposes). In the ticket example: 5250 / 30.41 = 172.64 AED per day.

The salary amount deducted from an employee's paycheck for days taken as unpaid leave (leave without pay / LWP). Calculated as: Daily Wage × Number of Leave Days. The deduction is locked at the time of calculation and cannot be automatically recalculated if public holidays are added later.

The employee's current salary setup in the system, including total salary amount and component breakdown. When a new salary configuration is created, it should be used for all subsequent calculations, including pending leave deductions.

When converting a partial year (incomplete final year of service) to a year fraction, the system divides the day count by 366 if the period includes a leap year, or by 365 if it does not. This affects the precision of the year fraction used in gratuity calculations.

A terminal benefit paid to an employee upon resignation or contract termination. Calculated based on basic salary, service duration, and contract type. For limited contracts, the system applies a tiered calculation: 21 days of daily wage per year for the first 5 years of service, and 30 days of daily wage per year for service beyond 5 years.

The total number of days an employee has worked, calculated from the date of joining to the date of departure. This must account for all calendar days including leap year days to ensure accurate gratuity calculations.

Ministry of Human Resources and Emiratisation (UAE regulatory body). MOHRE standards define the correct methodology for calculating End of Service gratuity benefits, including proper handling of leap years in service period calculations.

The proportional salary amount calculated for an employee based on their departure date, computed using the daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) multiplied by the number of days worked in the final month.
Leave accrual policy where employees earn leave days only at the end of each calendar month, after completing the full month. Incomplete months do not accrue leave days.
Leave accrual policy where employees earn leave days daily throughout the month, rather than waiting until month-end. Allows partial month accrual for mid-month departures.

The system breaks service duration into two tiers: (1) first 5 years of service (applies 21 days per year multiplier), and (2) service above 5 years (applies 30 days per year multiplier). Each tier is calculated separately and summed.
Gratuity calculation method that applies different daily wage multipliers based on service duration: 21 days per year for first 5 years of service, 30 days per year for service above 5 years.

The date on which an employee's employment ends (offboarding date). This date is used as the cutoff point for salary proration calculations. The ticket demonstrates the distinction between departure dates in the past vs. future relative to payroll processing.

A service duration range that determines the number of days of gratuity per year. For example, employees with 1-5 years of service may receive 21 days of gratuity per year, while those with 5+ years receive a different amount.
A contract type with a defined end date. Gratuity is calculated based on the contract end date (date of departure) and the contract start date (date of joining).

The total number of working days in an employee's tenure, calculated by summing working day periods and subtracting unpaid leave days. This value is used to determine years of service for gratuity calculations.

The duration of an employee's employment expressed in years, calculated by dividing days worked by 365 or 366. This is used to determine the gratuity entitlement bracket (e.g., 1 to 5 years = 21 days per year).

A system-wide setting for unpaid leave deductions that automatically overrides individual leave policy calculation methods. This configuration determines which salary component (basic or gross) and which divisor (working days, calendar days, or custom days) are used to calculate daily wage deductions for unpaid leave.

The process of computing compensation for leave periods based on the daily rate derived from the leave policy configuration. The calculation uses the daily rate (monthly salary divided by the configured divisor) multiplied by the number of leave days.
Salary adjusted for partial months, calculated by applying the daily rate (derived from policy configuration) to the actual number of days worked or on leave in that month.

The configuration setting in the daily wage calculator that determines how daily wage is calculated for leave salary accrual purposes. Options include 'working days' (daily wage varies by month based on working day count) and 'custom days' (daily wage remains stable across months).

The running total of leave salary amounts accrued for an employee across multiple months. Each month's accrual is added to the prior month's balance. The cumulative total is affected by the daily wage calculation method selected in leave encashment settings.

A leave encashment calculation method where the daily wage is derived using a fixed number of days (not tied to actual monthly working days). This maintains a stable daily wage rate across all months.

A configuration that defines how salary is deducted when an employee takes leave. It specifies the salary components to include (e.g., Basic Only or Basic + Allowances) and the daily wage divisor used to calculate the leave deduction amount.

A policy that defines which days of the week are working days and which are off/weekend days for an employee. This configuration directly determines how many working days are counted in proration calculations. For example, NVK Operations work week has all 7 days configured as working days with no weekends.

The system setting that defines how daily rates are calculated from monthly salaries. In the ticket example, the daily wage config was set to divide monthly salary by 30 days (21,000 ÷ 30 = AED 700 per day).

The time interval (typically monthly) during which payroll is calculated and processed. The ticket references the 'active payroll cycle' as the context in which prorated salary should be displayed for departing employees.

The process of determining an employee's daily pay rate based on their salary and a selected calculation basis (calendar days, working days, or custom days). This rate is used to calculate deductions for unpaid leave and other time-off scenarios.

An amount subtracted from an employee's salary in the payroll system, typically for unpaid leave, absences, or other adjustments. Deductions should be automatically created and removed based on leave request status and daily wage calculations.

A record in the system that links an approved unpaid leave request to a corresponding payroll deduction. Deleting a leave transaction is intended to allow recalculation of the deduction amount based on updated daily wage settings.

A nationally recognized day off that is excluded from working days calculations. Public holidays are country-specific (e.g., Egypt has different public holidays than other countries). When a public holiday is added to the system after a leave request is created, it affects the working days count for that period, potentially causing calculation mismatches.

The system component responsible for managing leave requests and calculating the number of leave days. It determines working days by subtracting weekends and public holidays from the total period. This module does not currently send complete leave request details to the Payroll module, causing synchronization issues.

The system component responsible for calculating daily wages and processing salary deductions. It calculates daily wage based on the configuration at the time of processing. Once calculated, the daily wage value is locked and does not update if public holidays are added later.

A configurable value (e.g., 30.42 days) used in the unpaid leave policy to calculate daily wage. The daily wage is calculated as monthly salary divided by the custom days divisor. This differs from using calendar days (28-31 days per month) and can produce different deduction amounts for the same leave period.

A calculation method for daily wage that divides the monthly salary by the actual number of days in that month (e.g., 29 for February in leap years, 31 for January). This is the basis for unpaid leave deductions when calendar days mode is configured.

A display section in the payroll deduction record that shows the calculation breakdown, including the daily rate and the number of days used as the divisor. In this ticket, the remarks field incorrectly displays 31 days for February instead of the actual 29 days.

The precedence order that determines which settings take effect when multiple configuration levels exist. In the daily wage calculator, the global unpaid leave daily rate configuration takes precedence over policy-level calculation method settings.

Settings configured at the individual leave policy level that specify how unpaid leave deductions should be calculated, such as Basic Salary / Working Days. These settings can be overridden by global configuration.
The calendar month during which the employee actually took unpaid leave. The daily rate for deduction should be calculated based on this month's working days, not the month when payroll is processed.
The month during which the payroll transaction is created or processed in the system. This may differ from the month when the leave actually occurred.
